JulieH: Yes--chemo twins :)  So, the Avastin trial is unaffected by the ruling, anyone enrolled will continue to carry out the Clinical Trial Protocol.  They are also allowed to continue to enroll until early Spring. Then they will be done. I'm still unsure about the Avastin; not sure I want to add yet another drug to a regimen that is already going to be very taxing on my body. That said, I'm triple negative...what if this Avastin is really the magic bullet, you know? On wigs and hair--I went to a wig place near my home (they do male and female hair loss), and the guy was really nice (kind of outgoing in a NewYork / Bronx kind of way) and helped me try on a few wigs (they had them right there in the store)...but they are like $600. Am I crazy for thinking this is WAY too much for a wig?  He mentioned that my insurance might pay for it...so I will call them today. I've also visited the TLC website and they have some cute stuff too. there's a thread on this board about hair loss options (I think it's pinned to the top of the Chemo board) and it has a lot of links / websites. I ordered a free scarf from FranceLuxe and I also emailed the other website (can't remember, starts with a G) for a free wrap. Hopefully those will come quickly. My biggest complaint with the wigs I tried on is that they don't look like me....but I have this really thin fine hair that's very straight.  The wigs all have this "pouf" up style at the crown of the head and it makes it seem like I'm 4 inches taller than I really am...and with way more hair. So i'm nervous. On the work front. I've been at the same company for 11years. I'd been looking for part time work for about a year (b/c my children are very small) I finally found a part time job that I was interested in (same company), so I applied (before I knew about the cancer, of course). They hired me, and want me to start Feb 1st. So I had to have the whole, "thanks for hiring me, and by the way, I've got cancer" conversation :P  That was fun. But the hiring mgr seems really really nice and understanding. The point of the story is, I need a good wig, but for only 3 days a week. My work sched is set to be T-W-R starting Feb 1st.  The other point of my story is; I'm taking a 40% pay cut, so I just can't see spending $600 on a wig I'm hoping to be able to manage working my new part time job through chemo, but we'll see. We're leaving the kids in daycare full time for now (since I don't know how I'll be with chemo, and the continuity is nice for them).  I originally wanted to do infusions on Fridays...but I can't now (my onc isn't there on Fridays, go figure) So they've started me on chemo on a Tues...and I'm hoping I can at least work my way up to going on Thursdays...like, Tues 18th, maybe Wed Feb 2, and then Thurs the 17th or something... Good luck to chemo sisters starting this week! Keep us posted with your experiences and SEs!

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 05:47AM slcst12 wrote: Tsundermann: I'm making a few changes since the dx. On the day of my lumpectomy, DH and I completely gave up diet coke. Cold Turkey. This was difficult for us, b/c we are not coffee drinkers. This was our morning thing...a can of Diet Coke. My all time favourite beverage of choice!  But there's really nothing of value in a diet coke, it's just chemical sludge So we quit. Otherwise, I've been doing fruit smoothies with leafy greens (I have great recipes if anyone is interested!) But on the A/C days, I really couldn't drink those. We definitely do a lot of vegetables, but these days I find myself buying more organic stuff. I've lost a bit of weight on chemo--I'm 5'5" and about 115 now, but got down to about 110 on the A/C. Normally I'm around 120lbs. On exercise...we bought a recubment bike at the suggestion of a friend who is struggling with ovarian cancer. Her onc told her to bike 30 mins a day and gave her 2 years to live. That was 6 years ago, so I figured a bike was a pretty good idea. I bike 30 mins a day (usually 35 or 40), but on the very worst of chemo days, I might only go like 3 miles (i can barely move my feet to pedal!) On a "feeling better" day, i can go about 7 miles. When I'm out of chemo, I will get my lazy ass back on the treadmill too, just to mix things up a bit.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 06:22AM slcst12 wrote: You ladies are truly an insipiration for me on these boards. I had my first A/C treatment on Tues and the Neulasta shot on Wed. Also, just to reiterate, (more for myself) I am making this decicison to do chemo, even though chemo is an evil bitch, I think it is the best option for me, so it helps (me) to think that I have some small control over my therapy. My darling (almost 4 year old) son sobbed his head off when he saw me Tues after treatment, and told me I "looked just awful", and he offered to have a special stay at home day to take care of me. Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 07:54AM slcst12 wrote: DD AC / T began 18-Jan Cycle 2 of AC, day 15 Hi Girls! Gearing up for round 3 of A/C tomorrow. Already starting to panic, knowing what's to come. Amelia: Thx for your comments about us mom's with young kids, gave me a huge boost to keep fighting! Aimee Mac: Lorazepam is Ativan, if you haven't already made that connection, I know there are others of us on it. They prescribed it for me as well, so I can share my experience here. It's supposed to relax you and ease the anxiety and the anxiety-induced nausea. I'm supposed to take it day of chemo, and a few days after. It does help with the racing brain / nausea, etc, but it makes me tired (this is OK with me, since during sleep is the only time i don't feel like I'm going to vomit). The only significant SE that I have had with it (and I'm not sure if it was the lorazepam or the zofran/compazine) was during treatment 2 I had really horrible constipation. Such that I thought I might have to go to the hospital. So...get your stool softener / miralax, or whatever and make sure you are religious with the dosing.  Hope this helps! On the hair: So--DH buzzed my head shortly after treatment #2, and most of the stubble fell out the last week or so...but I still have some up on the crown of my head...does anyone else have this? good luck to all our ladies getting treatment this week; I go in tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 08:35AM slcst12 wrote: DD AC * 4 (began 18-Jan) then DD Taxol *4 began 17-Mar Hi ladies!! I finished up my first DD Taxol yesterday. JulieH: My fingertips are so sore, I can't even use them...I've started to turn on my electric toothbrush button with the middle of my thumb, you know? It's crazy! But, like you, way less nausea. Thank goodness. I am still taking emend (preventative measure) since I struggled so much with nausea on A/C. But I haven't had to take nearly the zofran or compazine that I needed on A/C.  On the neulasta...my doc said I don't need it, but I *am* dose dense on Taxol. Weird. I did ask her to pull a vitamin D level and she agreed, so I should get the results soon. Although, she went on to say that most of us would have a low Vit D level since it's wintertime (not enough going outside). She also said that she wouldn't know what to do with the results anyway. I think the US Recommended Daily Allowance of vitamin D was set to prevent Rickets. I don't think that RDA value takes breast cancer into account! Melissa hi!!! I 've been wondering about you!  Like Julie, I won't sugar coat the A/C. For me it was brutal. Treatment one was especially hard b/c i had the port put in and the chemo all in the same day. But Tx 2-3-4 were also extremely difficult for me. Nausea, constipation and fatigue (in that order) were my most difficult side effects. It took me a while to get the meds sorted out (most of the anti nausea meds create worse constipation than just chemo alone) but I did finally figure out to just STAY on the stool softener the whole time. I thought I could just take it starting the day before chemo. NOPE. Also...get some Miralax that stuff rocks. For me: My doc recommneded the L-glutamine (which I have) to prevent neuropathy. I don't know how much to take, but she said it's on the bottle. My bottle is just loose powder though, so hopefully they'll give me a teaspoon amount or something :) Good luck to all our girls getting chemo this week!

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 09:10PM slcst12 wrote: Hi everyone! Hope you are all enjoying the 3 day weekend and time off from the spark-o-nator (that's what I mentally call the rads machine...) Hey...whatever helps me get through the day:) On the scractch-offs: Of the 5 I've scratched off so far, two were "winners" as in "you have won a free ticket!" On the breathing: My RO told me to breathe normally too...I think this is quite hokey...given all the precise and specific measurements on the instruments / table. I finally said something to the RO about it, to the effect of "what's up with this? like...how accurate is this crap really?" He totally agreed that it's imprecise and admitted that they irradiate the "prostate guys and they move around all the time..." He went on to say that most people gripe about heart problems and blame rads, but it's really the adriamycin that knocks the heart back. (I actually agree with this--see my earlier post about being concerned with the adriamycin--it's a derivative of mustard gas for crying out loud.) On the tamoxifen and oncotypes: I can't answer these, I'm triple negative, so I don't get tamoxifen and the Oncotype testing/scores don't work on me either.  It's a little like flying blind. On the skin / bra: I haven't noticed anything unusual yet (have completed only 5/33 so far) and am still wearing my bra and only putting on some eucrin cream at night. I did notice that my scar from port removal is a bit pink, but otherwise i'm good... Posts.Content: May 16, 2011 09:07PM slcst12 wrote: welcome ftblmom and Jean H :) Ftblmom, I was just like you, and nearly fell over when I saw this gi-normous 3 inch scar on my boob from my lumpectomy. they don't tell you stuff like that. Also. I got told I'd "lose my hair" not, "my eyelashes, and my nose hair too" They sort of left that part out.  Thanks to all for posting your experiences with rads. I start next Mon the 23rd. I already have my tattoos (they are very small, like a pin-point) and i'm ready to roll. Thx also Julie H for posting about Tom's Of Maine. I ordered some, but haven't tried it yet. I worry now that it will be a slimy mess. I'm *so* not going until July 8th with no deodorant. That's just the way it is. Another question for everyone: My RO told me no shaving that area for the duration of treatment. Really? Like, is this what all of your all's docs told you too? B/c seriously, I so should have been diagnosed so that I could have had rads in the winter... LOL Take it easy everyone!

Posts.Content: May 23, 2011 08:19PM slcst12 wrote: Gina: I'm LOL at your "boob whiplash" comment :) Tinaj: Sorry your scratch off haven't been winners yet...there's always hope! For me: I had my first treatment today. It was OK. Long drive to get there though (~45 mins) and I have the 7:15 time slot, so I left my house at 6:25 this morning. So far so good. I forgot, and wore my underwire bra. I'm ok for now. The only real discomfort I have is b/c they removed my port on Friday. The doc was in there scraping all over the place until I was finally like, "Dude..what are you doing?" He said, "I'm disrupting some of this scar tissue" So, OK--that disruption left some pretty serious bruising on my chest and boob. My port was in my cancer side, so they wanted it out before radiation could begin. Anyway, I'm kinda tired today, but seriously, not from radiation at all, from having my 4 yr old and 2 yr old boys with me today :) Take care everyone!
